As a seasoned monster hunter from the PS2 era, diving into Monster Hunter: World felt like reuniting with an old friend. The animations and combat mechanics are top-notch, and yes, even the in-game steak grilling song is 😙👌 *chef's kiss*. The game runs smoothly, a testament to its fine optimisation.​

Teaming up with friends, many of whom are newcomers, has been a blast. One buddy, Tobay, even schooled me on game mechanics—talk about a role reversal! However, I must admit, the early-game (and some late-game) weapon designs feel a bit uninspired compared to the unique aesthetics of older titles. It's a minor gripe in an otherwise stellar game.​

Now, if only Monster Hunter Wilds' PC launch was as good as World's. Get it together, Capcom!

Monster Hunter: World lets you live out your fantasy of becoming a glamorous beast slayer, just be prepared to spend hours grinding for that one rare scale and carting (dying) more times than you'd like to admit. The monsters are epic, the weapons are ridiculously oversized, and the satisfaction of finally felling a giant lizard is only slightly overshadowed by the realization you now have to carve it up for its shinier bits. If you enjoy epic boss fights and the endless pursuit of slightly better loot, prepare to lose hundreds of hours to this addictive monster-mashing masterpiece.
Still the goat. Put on the ICE mod and it becomes a near-perfect game.

I have over 1k hours on the playstaion, and I was looking forward to Wilds to come out, and don't get me wrong, Wilds has done a great job with the combat but this game is far superior in charm, colors, and weapon design...especially once iceborne was released. I booted this game back up today and just was taken back by the maps, the colors, the music, etc. It's a little slow going at first but once it gets going, it's hard to stop playing. I booted up wilds after playing and opened up the maps, looked at the boring roster and shut it back down. I think when I want a MH fix, I'll play this. I also enjoy rise, but can't seem to find people who play it at a lower rank. If there was I'd play that as well. I have a few hundred hours on the Switch but the visuals aren't there compared to the PC version, so I don't load that one up as much.
Hunts, monsters, eating, this game is another masterpiece from CAPCOM and It's one of my favorite games ever!

Monster Hunter: World and its expansion, Iceborne, are more than just action RPGs—they're a form of therapy. There's something incredibly satisfying about diving into a vast world where my only objective is to track, fight, and carve up massive beasts, all to forge stronger weapons and armor. The game’s core loop—hunt, gather, craft, repeat—is a cycle that absorbs me completely, helping me vent my frustrations through sheer determination and skill.

At its core, Monster Hunter: World and Iceborne give me control. No matter how chaotic real life gets, I know that in this game, with enough effort, I can overcome any challenge. And that’s exactly why I keep coming back.

[h2] Nergigante is the reason I work out. [/h2]

⠀⠀⠀I have this fantasy where we start talking at the Vanity Fair Oscars party bar. We exchange a few pleasantries—he asks what I do. I say I loved him in Monster Hunter: World. He laughs and I get my drink.
⠀⠀⠀"Well, it was a pleasure to meet you," I say abruptly and walk away. I've got his attention now. How many guys would voluntarily leave a conversation with Nergigante? He touches his scales impatiently as he watches me leave.
⠀⠀⠀Later, as the night's dragged on and the coterie of gorgeous narcissists grows increasingly loose, he finds me on the balcony, my bow tie undone, smoking a cigarette.
⠀⠀⠀"Got a spare?" he asks cordially. I knew there was something to be had for playing hard to get, but I wasn't expecting it to be so effective this quickly.
⠀⠀⠀"What's in it for me?" I reply as I hand him one of my little white ladies. The lavender lips at the end of his triangular snout form a gentle smile.
⠀⠀⠀Sarcasm charges his response. "Conversation with me, duh." Sharing his sentiment, I laugh this time, despite feeling somewhat out of my comfort zone. I believe myself to be different from the aforementioned gorgeous narcissists that are so ever-present, but I can’t help but feel as if I’m somewhere I have no place being. There are semantics to a red carpet that fit a different bill than I have ever personally identified with.
⠀⠀⠀He tilts his head slightly to my right, allowing the pearlescent glow from the golden chandelier above us to give his eyes, in all their amber glory, a sheen that was otherwise not present. "What's so funny?" he protests.
⠀⠀⠀Had my laugh come off as snarky? "Nothing, nothing... It's just... don't you grow tired of the egos?"
⠀⠀⠀"You get used to it," he says, lighting his cigarette and handing me back the lighter. “There’s not always enough fame to go around.” He was a professional—gentle and slow in his movements, not a single ounce of energy wasted. The way he snapped the metal head of my Zippo shut produced a satisfactory click with a different air of authority than I was used to.
⠀⠀⠀"What would you do if you weren't a divinely powerful spike-launching dragon?" I ask. My throat feels the urge to chuckle slightly again, but I stop myself out of a desire for a deeper authenticity to our conversation.
⠀⠀⠀"Teaching, I think."
⠀⠀⠀His tail flicks the ground softly—just once—its spikes smacking loudly against the wooden footrest of the barstool. "And if I was your student, what would I be learning?"
⠀⠀⠀"Discipline," he blurts, breaking the eye contact we’d been holding since we started smoking. His tail flicks the oak floor once more as his lips purse together slightly. A small rock shoots from his nose, falling predictably to the floor as it meets an unremarkable oblivion. “Control,” he mutters softly, hastily under his breath, looking back up into my eyes before changing the subject. "Where are you from?"
⠀⠀⠀"New Zealand," I say. I slowly twirl my glass in a circle before setting it down on the counter. It’s hard not to stare at the liquor and the two large ice cubes spinning centrifugally in unison for a few moments. My hands grasp together and I turn in my seat to the right, our eye contact broken again thanks to my decision to stare at the wall of extravagant bottles in front of me instead.
⠀⠀⠀"Oh, wow. That's lovely."
⠀⠀⠀"It's okay," I admit. "Not everything is to my liking."
⠀⠀⠀"What could possibly be not to your liking in New Zealand?" he inquires. “The weather, the scenery, the healthcare! I’ve always imagined it to be quite lavish.” His tail flicks against the floor again, then the lower half of his stool. He grabs his bony cauda impatiently and sits it under his right thigh.
⠀⠀⠀"I don't like sand," I tell him. "It's coarse and rough and irritating and it gets everywhere." It's easy to see some cogs start turning in his head once I say that. Perhaps he's not a fan of sand either? Maybe it bothers his scales?

It's a monster hunter game without the jank from the previous titles--maybe a little bit jank but not as much, you won't notice it, i promise. 
You hunt monster and then turn their skin into something you wear or use to kill other monsters, do this for another hundreds of hours;  this cycle is what you should expect when you buy any monster hunter games.

I love this cycle of insanity and i won't stop until i find a good reason to go on with my life. And then i'll play Rise and then Wilds.

My introduction to the Monster Hunter series.

I'm usually no fan of JRPGs, but boy this checks so many boxes when it comes to gaming for me.

Solo play, progression, difficulty curve, and so many others I would be writing about it for as long as I plan to play it.
It's not a perfect game - the menu system could get a serious makeover (*cough* it didn't on Wilds *cough*) but honestly it won't get in the way once you figure all the information in it.
There's a good amount of grinding involved once you get to the endgame, which I think is a negative for people who don't enjoy it. I'd rather be able to target rewards and items I need to progress rather than rely on a <0.1% chance to get what I need.

Aaaand multiplayer - also not fixed on Wilds - is a hassle, but if you're like me and basically have no friends, that won't be an issue ;)

Get this, and for all that's holy and dear to you, stick to it like I stuck to monsters with my Zero Sum Discharges.

One of the best ARPGs Ive played so far and definitely one of my favourite games overall. 
And It is still stays true even after release of Wilds and Rise.

The combat feels just right, with enough depth and commitment to every move you do. Id even say it might feel like a turned-based action game, where both you and the monster take your respective turns to punish eachother.
Thankfully, its not a game where you button-mash your way to victory, especially in later fights, you HAVE TO learn monster's moveset and especially your weapon's moveset, otherwise you either fail by carting or just time-out. And it feels great to learn that stuff and improve as a player. And there is alot to learn for each of 14 available weapons, that even after hundred of hours you still might learn new things even about a single weapon you main.
You dont get better in the game just by getting better gear or leveling up your stats, you get better in the game by learning its mechanics.

The monsters design is overall great, especially in Iceborne and its TUs. While there are some outliers, it doesnt take away from the greats like Velkhana, Namielle, Alatreon, Fatalis, Rajangs, Odogarons, Anjanaths, Zinogres and so on and so forth. Id say over half of the roster is great, the other half is either good or good enough. And then there are few like Lavasioths, Zorah and other Leshens, which Id say are just not fun to fight, thankfully you dont have to do most of them multiple times.
This is probably the only game where you can kill monster 100s of times and everytime it still feels fun to engage with it.
I would've never thought that even grind for Decos and Materials might be so fun for hundreds of hours either just by doing Guiding Lands and slaying everything in sight or killing Tempered Teostra 300 times.

Depsite it being a 7 y.o game, it still looks great even now, even in comparison to the 6th gen. And runs great even on mid hardware.

The only negative thing I can say about the game is probably story, but it doesnt take that much time to finish it, and you still get to experience alot of great monsters in there.

It might be hard to get into, especially if you havent played a game like that before, but its a rewarding experience for sure. You can always try and read in-game tutorials which give you some basic info or just look some more in-depth ones on platforms like YT.
Some times frustrating, but overall one of my favorites videogames saga
